head_text.subj: A SERIES OF IMAGES AND SOUNDS, (INT.HOSPITAL 0.R.)

text: emerge from the darkness: A blast of light like an interrogation room, the flatline BEEP of an EKG machine. NURSE straddles a MAN, unconscious on the gurney. She pum his chest with all her might, her hair falling loose from the red bandana that holds it in place.

Swarm around the gurney. Faces covered, dressed in scrub suits, they look like green androids..A moment later, the SURGEON makes his entrance like-Caesar. Tufts of black ha poke through his V-neck surgical suit. NURSES and AIDS ju to his every request. He pulls the nurse from the patient chest. Voiced=over dialogue is couriterpoint to the scene. It fa in first as two women LAUGHING...The first to speak SOUND distinctly Afro-American, South Boston.
George W. and Dick Cheney jump out of a plane. Who hits the ground first?
I dunno. Who?

Who cares? Afro-American hands pass a syringe to the surgeon who administers the lidocaine to the dying man. Nothing. Stil flatliner. The nurse in the bandana hands two paddles to Surgeon. The paddles are placed on the man's chest. A bea The man's chest arcs and falls. The American eagle tatooe on his flabby white bicep wiggles helplessiy.
Okay, why do polish dogs have pug noses?
Why? :

From chasing parked cars. The surgeon rips the man's chest armpit to armpit. Someon hands him a spreader. The surgeon places the instrument o the ribs and cranks open the chest exposing the shrunken blue-grey heart. The surgeon shoves his hands into the ch and begins to massage the tiny, broken organ.
What's brown and'white and looks good on a lawyer?
What?

A pit bull. The flatline never changes. After a few beats, the surgeo removes his hand from the chest, walks away briskly. The rest of the personnel follow except for the nurse in the bandana. She stares at the room which looks like Beirut a a bombing. Pulling the spreader from the man's chest, the nurse gently covers him as she would an ailing child. Alo she begins to clean up the mess.
You know how to save a doctor from drowning?
No.
Good. cur TO:

Two of the nurses just seen are the women we've heard tel jokes. The Afro-American’ nurse (WINNIE) is lean, dark, " The nurse in the red bandana is DENISE, early "30"s, exceptionally pretty but with eyes fresh with disappointm and an attitude tinged with sarcasm. She looks as if she just figured out that life is a great cosmic joke with a punch line. The last name on her name tag reads DEFIORE (pronounced De-fury). It fits. The women scan the back st for someone.
Where the hell are they? Okay, why do hummingbirds hum?
Why?
They don't know the words.
That's a sorry ass joke, Denise.
Gimme a break here. What's the ETA on those bozos?
Fifteen minutes. SOUNDS of a quickly approaching vehicle. Headlights splas the dock. A siren SOUNDS. We think it's an ambulance. It' a pizza delivery truck. Dialogue overlaps.
A siren. What an asshole.
It's about time. The driver of the pizza truck hops out with a large box.
Siren's a tease. Just for you.
You ‘bout as funny as a crutch. (examines the pizza) Double sausage, bacon, extra cheese. In the b.g. a real ambulance is HEARD.
Oh shit.
Wait. Maybe it's goin' uptown. The ambulance SOUNDS again. Much closer. Another NURSE ap at the double doors.
Hey campers, we got a black male, shotgun to the gut.
Damn. You know the other night I had five gunshot wounds, three stabbings...
---and a partridge in a pear tree. A fresh-faced, nervous INTERN steps onto a dock.
(sotto) Is he old enough to shave?

He's not even old enough to fuck. Winnie laughs out loud, snorts. The ambulance SCREAMS aro the corner stops on a dime at the back of the loading doc a Boston police car on its tail. Paramedics pull the blee MAN from the ambulance, his stomach blown open by a doubl barrel blast....we HEAR..."BP eighty over forty... pulse forty as the gurney pushes inside the hospital.
It's suddenly, weirdly silent except for the gurney wheel squeaking wildly over the tile floor. Denise, Winnie, the paramedic and even the cops exchange looks, wait for the intern to bark orders.
(to the intern) What'll it be, Ace? We gotta fix this guy so Boston's finest can interrogate him to death. The intern mumbles, exhausted, panicked. The man's chest gurgles. :
Ten cc's of lidocaine.
Lidocaine? That was the sucker's lung collapsing. The intern mumbles incoherently. We HEAR, "BP sixty over forty..." It's now or never, so Denise takes over.

Get a tube in his chest.... Denise continues to bark orders over the gurney as it rol down the hall to the OR...we HEAR..."large bore IV..." The intern shakes, confused and alone. After a few beats, when it registers that a nurse has taken charge, the inte comes to life, chases the gurney, shouting.
Wait. I'm the doctor here! CUT To:
Winnie paces, glances at the door that reads "Jim Rivera Director of Nursing” - 0.8. Denise is HEARD, "He choked..
FIND RIVERA, his tense face pock-marked like the moon. Denise's voice is like the low growl of a doberman on a s leash.
-+-he was the doctor on call.
He's an asshole.
You know the rules.
The rules don't say I gotta wait for some moron to figure out which end of the stethoscope to use.
We're offering you a suspension. Without pay, of course.
What a deal.
I'd take it if I were you. It could “ be worse.
Yeah. How?
The family of the dead boy isn't pressing charges. A long pause.
This stinks.
Off the record. You're right.
I'm not taking the suspension.
I didn't say it was a choice. f * A stand-off. i we
Then I quit. cuT To:
Denise scans the highway, brow furrowed. Across from her SAM, age ten. He knows she's worried.
Ma, how many psychiatrists does it take to change a light bulb?
I give.
None. The light bulb has gotta want to change itself. Get it? Denise looks at her son tenderly, wipes cherry filling fr his lips, plops a Celtics hat on his head.

Yeah, I get it, smartypants. A_car horn HONKS in the b.g. Denise stiffens when she see MITCH, a swarthy Italian, waving from his muscle car. APR sits next to him. Barbie-doll pretty, all smiles. Sam jum up to leave.
(to Sam) Six o'clock. No excuses. GIL, the 50+ Italian donut shop owner, catches Sam.
How 'bout a hug for your old uncle. Sam hugs Gil, kisses his mom, bolts for the door.
{about April) That woman has more teeth than the winner of the Kentucky Derby. Denise starts to go.
Denise, wait. Gil takes her hand, puts a wad of cash in it. Denise's ja tightens. Crying is out of the question.
She puts the cash in Gil's shirt pocket, shakes her head, "no".
What's an old man like me gonna do with extra cash?
Spend it on blondes? A look passes between them. Gil gently puts the cash back Denise's hands.
You're the only good man I know.
And don't you forget it.
A pasty, over-weight PERSONNEL DIRECTOR skims her compute while chewing a milky way as if it were cud. Denise waits
I've got a position as temp nurse at Liberty Street.
What is that..a shoe store?
Convalescent. Sort of.
Forget it. Not my speed.
That's the best I can do, hot shot.
(getting up) I'll get back to you.
With all the trauma centers closing-- I've got nothing in an ER. Denise looks dejected.
Look, I'd take the swing shift.
I have no openings, I'm sorry.
++-come to think of it I do have something...a new hospital is recruiting...would you consider re- locating to Nova Scotia? Denise sinks lower in her chair. cur To:
Denise sits across the table from a blowzy blonde (MARION with a no-nonsense jaw, who shuffles through legal briefs
Taking a moral stand is admirable if you're Jesse Jackson. So, as your lawyer, I suggest...
Wait a minute, I don't want to hear that Mitch has a chance...
With you out of work, you better believe it. He makes his support payments, sees Sam regularly...
He disappeared for three months with a bimbo.
A bimbo he's planning to marry. Frankly, I think he has a good chance of getting joint custody. You could have a worse guy for an ex.
Yeah, maybe Charles Manson. Look, you don't get it. (MORE)
If he gets joint custody, it means he has a say in what Sam does; which means he has a say in what I do and there's no way in heli that slimy bastard is gonna control me anymore.
Still planning on moving to California with Sam?
If I didn't have so many damn lawyer bills I'd be long gone.
Maybe you should've thought about that before you quit your job.
(stung) You know what's brown and white and looks good on a lawyer?
I've heard it. Get a job, Denise. Any job.
Denise on the phone.
-+-yeah, this is Denise DeFiore. You know that job at that, what did you call it...Liberty Street?

In her well-worn Ford escort, Denise passes a sign from t Massachusetts Historical Society that marks the entrance a township called "Danvers". Denise rushes past Cape Cods and federal houses heavy wit tradition. She checks the address of @ square, brick hous with a white picket fence. ivy climbs the front face of 1 Liberty Street from the ground to the widow's walk that c the hipped roof.
Denise knocks. After a few beats a black man in a three- Piece suit (CHARLIE), age indeterminate, answers.
You from the registry?
That's me. Sorry I'm... CHARLIE . (about her uniform) You bring extra clothes?
No.
That'll have to do. On Denise's quizzical look.
as it dips and bobs close on a COUPLE, mid-fifties. He is ruddy-faced and uncomfortable in a rented tux; she wears "mother-of-the-bride” polyester copy. She dabs her eyes.
+.-and on this occasion I am reminded of a verse in the Song of Solomon...

The home video camera widens and swerves to reveal the co among the other guests. White satin, lots of doves and to tall floral arrangements thinly disguise the banquet room a wedding chapel. The video camera pans across the aisle the groom's PARENTS whose expressions are pinched.
"My beloved is mine and I am his, he pastures his flock among the lilies...until the day breathes and the shadows flee....
from the amateur camera person... A little BoY runs his Ninja Turtle up the shoulder of a l GIRL who's fallen asleep in het mother's lap...
"...turn, my beloved, be like a gazelle, or a young stag upon rugged mountains.”

» Mt c€ oY, ll. Two WOMEN in their eighties sit beside a wheel-chair boun young woman (GRETCHEN) who wears horn-rimmed glasses. The wheel~chair is decorated with white satin ribbons and pin flowers. Behind Gretchen, a SOLDIER eyes a buxom REDHEAD across the aisle. His WIFE notices and elbows him sharply
+.-for loving someone is like holding sand... Denise stands at the back of the room beside an Ichabod- Crane looking man (MAX) who's in a wheelchair. Denise's l is distant.
++-close your hand tightly and. the sand drains away. Leave your hand open and the sand remains. The amateur camera person moves behind the minister.
the bride (ROSE) and the groom (BENJAMIN) gaze at one ano from matching wheelchairs. Both are crippled by cerebral Palsy. Ben takes Rose's withered hand in his.
Ben, repeat after me. I Ben, take thee, Rose... Denise has had it. She slips out the back door.

Denise escapes into the claustrophobic hallway rancid wit smoke and earth-tone’ carpets. She pulls a cigarette from bag, lights up. In the b.g. a loud "NO" stops her action. young man (RICK) wearing a trench coat and fedora ‘a la B is mid~argument with Charlie.
No. No. I...I won't go.

Rick, I can't leave you alone. Denise stares. There's something wrong, but what? Rick is mid-twenties with the build of a running back. His face i boyishly handsome but there is something....disconnected. about him. Charlie gently tugs him by the arm.
(too loud) No. You can't make me. You can't.
CHARLIE ; i Now what did we agree on, huh? & Rick clasps his hands to his ears, swings from side to si the gestures exaggerated, his reactions extreme.
I don't have to, I don't have to, I don't, I don’t.
(sotto, to herself) Great. Loonies. I hate loonies. She starts to walk away. Hears a "hey you" but keeps walk Then a "Denise." She grimaces, busted.

Stay with Rick for me. And make sure he doesn't run off anywhere. Denise forces a resigned smile. Charlie ducks back into t ceremony. Rick looks Denise up and down, nothing subtle i his examination of her. Denise sense his desire to speak, but he can't engage his brain. He strains, searching for every word. When he speaks, his voice is thick and Slight monotone. Even so, Rick's eyes, when they connect, reveal natural intelligence.
You're, you're not Kelly.
Good call, Ace.

I'm not, not Ace. I'm Ricky. (in a deeper, "man's" voice) I mean, Rick. (a kid's voice again) And, and I'm not gonna talk until, until Kelly c..comes. Rick plops on the floor, cross-legged in protest.
Fine by me. (lights a cigarette) Wanta hear a joke? It's a good one. My kid told it to me. He's smart. (no answer) How many psychiatrists does it take to change a light bulb? (MORE)
(no answer) None. The light bulb has gotta want to change itself. Rick stares at her, blankly.
You got quite a sense of humor.
(about the cigarette) Those...those stink.
Hey, you wanta talk or you don't wanta talk, I don't care. But don't bust my chops. .
If you, you don't stop that, I'll run, run away.
Is that so. A stand-off. Rick scrambles to his feet, darts down the h Denise chases after him. She swears. He's fast.
Hey, hey gimme a break here.
Rick runs down the long hallway and out an emergency exit Sirens SCREECH.

Rick covers his ears, screams along with the sirens. Deni catches him, tries to calm him down. Hotel personnel scur to the scene. Denise turns to see the wedding party and a of the guests spill into the Parking lot, dismayed. Charl glares at Denise.
Just a little misunderstanding. Everything's under control... cur To:
Denise on the phone. In the b.g. she watches a poker game between Rick, Gretchen, Max and BRIDGET, a red-head with mild Downs. Rick wears his fedora.
Bridget arranges her cards for the eighth time, sings alo with the TV...the "Brady bunch, the Brady bunch... A bug- eyed, mildly crippled woman (JUSTINE) struggles, but mana to pull up a chair.
Mitch, I'm gonna be a little late.
Why doesn't Sam just stay over?
Because it's only a few minutes. {sotto, looking around) Look, nobody wants to get outta here tonight more than me.
You know we could avoid this lawyer thing...
Oh, so you're givin' up?
No way. For Chrissakes what about Sam? We can give him more. April is home all day...

(keeping her voice down) April isn't his mother. I'll be home by eight. Be there. Denise paces absently half-watching the poker game. Rick deals, counts to himself. Max and Bridget sing the theme song, arrange their cards. Poker dialogue is HEARD..."Hit me. Hit me.”
(to Denise) ) Hey, you play poker?
Yeah.
Grab a chair. (about Bridget) She needs a coach. Denise figures "what the hell", pulls up a chair next to "Red". Rick gives her a furtive glance. Denise hears a he LAUGH. DENISE'S Pov
Cc

Across the hall, the library of the old house is used as Administrator's office. LUCY ZACHARY has the title. She i mid-forties, a she~bear of a woman. She talks rapid-fire the phone, feet up on a cherry~wood desk. The front door opens and in blasts DEREK, early "20"'s, D Syndrome. He wears a "Chicken Lickin" Delivery Hat. He sl behind Justine, tickles her.
Tex, you she-devil. So how was the wedding? Ad lib answers. Derek eyes the cards. Looks at Rick, jeal apparent.
(to Rick) Hey, Bogie. Poker’s only five cards. You're so dense... Rick is red-faced, flustered. Ad-lib from the others..."l off, Derek..." Rick breathes heavily, stares at the table
Hey, it's not my fault he's hopeless... A pause. Denise stares hard at Derek. She hates bullies.

It's another game. He just forgot, the first two cards are down, the rest are up. It's called stud poker. Everyone reacts to the word "stud" as adolescents would. lib "oooh, Rick"... He smiles, vindicated. A look passes between Denise and Rick. A truce. Derek grimaces. Charlie appears, wearing an apron.

(to the group) Do I look like Betty Crocker to you? You all get your butts in the kitchen. Help me get dinner, The game breaks up amid grumbling. Derek darts away with look that promises a future show down. Rick lage behind, approaches Denise. All is forgiven.
I...I like you... You're, you're pretty. Pretty.
Even if I'm not Kelly?
Ny

(a blank look) Kelly? {a distant memory) Oh yeah. You, you're prettier. (a pause) Well. Bye. He waves a wild "goodbye" on his to the kitchen. Denise doesn't know quite what to make of this odd man. A beat. Lucy enters, talking out loud.
What a day. Kelly's out for the duration with a complicated pregnancy and I'm out a nurse. (to Denise) Who're you? Denise's look says she's about to take advantage of this situation. curt TO:
Lucy clips down toward the kitchen. Denise half-jogs behi
Do you. know what Freud wrote?
Freud? Lucy | "The final therapy is love and work." Denise looks rueful. What does that have to do with her?
Denise follows Lucy. Justine, Max, Gretchen help Charlie with dinner. Rick smiles at Denise. Watches her. She does notice. The others do. Lucy What's for dinner, Tex?
Chili.
iucy huffs and puffs. Denise is close behind.  17. r™ LUCY . " They take turns with the menu. Her Q chili could take the skin off a snake.

Restored wallpaper and oak wainscoating. Denise and Lucy. Lucy Five bedrooms up, three down. Eight residents. Rose and Ben are our first married couple. You know the word, "Convalescent". It's supposed to mean, "become well again." Most of the time it translates as "waiting to die". Trust me, nobody waits at Liberty Street. For anything.
Good. .

You bet it's good. And if anybody on the outside refers to this place as a “home” they answer to me. (points at the rooms) Gretchen's a librarian, sharp as a tack that one; Tex is a clerk, Max works for a publishing firm as an indexer. Everybody who lives here learns to go out in the world just like you and me.
Teach ‘em to join the rat race, huh. Sometimes I'm not so sure it's an advantage. Lucy You would if you couldn't do it. A pause. Denise considers the implications.
What about that guy, Rick? Lucy He's new. We're still trying to place him in a job.
rs He seems, I don't know...different. R f LUCY Lo Head trauma. Hit by a car when he was sixteen.

Jesus. Lucy Oh, he's on the road to recovery. {on her look) His memory's not great, he's easily frustrated and he's got a helluva temper but his IQ is well above normal. Physically, he's fine. Mentally, emotionally, that's something else. His mom's kept him at home much too isolated.

Will he ever be...uh... Lucy "Normal?" Whatever that is. (shaking her head)) Our toughest case. He's a grown man with the personality of a moody adolescent because his mother refuses to let go. Our job is to channel all that energy.
Rick's or his mother's?
Both. So. Why'd you quit the E.R.?
(off guard) Let's say management and I had a parting of the ways.
Okay. This place is a far cry from meatball surgery.

Sounds good so far. Lucy The work is one on one, mostly tedious and very repetitive. There's no instant gratification, no adrenalin highs and I haven't saved a life since the cat choked on a fur ball.
Look, you need a nurse and I need a job. Do we have a deal or what?
(chuckles) Okay, you've got a shot. But don't think you can phone it in, Denise. Folks here aren't street-wise but, believe me, they're also not potted Plants. See you Monday.
In a white-bread ghetto in a town called Peabody saved fr terminal despair by the dense New England foliage.

Denise stares at Sam's empty room a glass of wine in her hand. It's filled with stuff little boys love. Nintendo. Spiderman poster. Roller blades. The phone RINGS. Denise jumps, runs for it, FOLLOW HER to the living room. Chaos. There's a dining room table sans chairs, a TV dinn on a cardboard box un-eaten. A map of the U.S. is pinned the wall with the route from Massachusetts to California high-lighted in bright orange. The tape machine picks up. f™
A I don't feel like talking so leave a message if you want.
It's Marion. We're going to court. No date set. Court's jammed...
Denise swears, turns down the volume, pours more wine. cUT TO:
Denise checks her watch; broods. In the b.g. Gil swears i Italian at a red-headed BOY with a mouthful of braces.
Cruellers. You burned my cruellers!
I'm sorry, Mr. Giambalvo.

Sorry. You're always sorry. Get out of here with "sorry". Go on... oo The red-headed boy grabs his backpack, rushes to the d Gil sees Denise searching the highway, chewing her nails. hands her a cream puff.  20.
Since my Sylvia died, may-she-rest- in-peace, I fell in love with only one other woman.
A big mistake.

You're telling me. The dreams I had. Sylvia haunted me for weeks. Every night I saw her. (Denise eyes him) Okay, it could have been I had bad pepperoni. I don't know. (she shakes her head) Come on now. You're gonna give yourself an ulcer. Mitch's muscle car pulls in, screeches to a stop.
He's still Sam's papa.
Don't remind me. Mitch sees Denise, ignores her. Denise grimaces at him, a Sam races into the donut shop. He opens his backpack, separates his weekend clothes from his schoolwork.
Sammy, where you been?
Sorry, Mom. We got back too late. Dad bought me skiis.
Skiis. Does he think every weekend is Christmas? And anyway, there's no snow.
There is in Canada.
Canada. He took you to Canada. That's another country.
I know, ma. We had it in geography. April has a cabin. Denise slides a look to Gil.
Dad thinks I should spend the summer with them, you know to have a family atmosphere and stuff. Denise is stung. She grabs Sam's stuff, pushes him ahead her out the door.
We'll be in California by then, remember? A "family atmosphere". What does he think I am, chopped liver?
Denise chases Derek, aka "Mr. Chicken Lickin" with his forgotten lunch. Rick trails, watching her closely.
Denise and Gretchen walking and chatting jostle by Rick, is too attentive, nervous and always in Denise's path.
Widen to reveal Denise and the residents listening to a T GUIDE. Rick's focuses on Denise; he mimics her reactions.
Rick tags too-close behind Denise as she does her chores.
Charlie and Denise work on a cranky hot water heater. Ric is perched on the stairs, watching... always watching.
(to Charlie, sotto) What's with him?
Rick. He's bored. And he likes you. Hey, who knows what goes on in that head. Rose played checkers with him once and he asked her to marry him.
He's driving me nuts. cur To:

The residents are watching a video. NARRATOR . ...latex condoms help to prevent the spread of disease, particularly AIDS... Rick, uncomfortable, shifts in his chair. Derek slumps. Justine, Max and Bridget watch, interested, but blase.
++-the condom should be fitted over the penis before sexual intercourse...
No joke. This is stupid. The women "shush” him. The NARRATOR continues in the b.g. Derek pulls a dirty picture from his wallet, pushes it in Rick's face. His mouth drops open like he's been harpoone
How'd ya like to pork that one?
P... pork?
(turning to the guys) Shut-up scumbags. Rick looks hurt. Derek laughs.
{to Derek) Shut up. You shut up. Rick stomps from the room, disturbed, confused. He Passes Denise in the hallway, a look of anguish on his face.
Is the video over? (Rick shakes his head "no") You gotta question? (a more vigorous "no") What's the problem?
Bath...bathroom. Rick escapes down the hallway leaving Denise annoyed.

Rick slams the door like he's chased by demons. He leans back on it, Sweating, eyes shut. After a few beats he ste to the mirror, looks at his face. His hand reaches up, to the shadow of his beard. He examines the hair poking thro his shirt. He looks frightened as if the face looking bac at him is foreign.
{to the mirror) Ricky...where is Ricky? He repeats his name as if it were connected to a distant memory. Someone POUNDS on the door. He jumps.
Hey, stop playing with yourself. Other people have gotta go. cUT TO:

Part of the yard has been paved to make way for half-cour basketball. A slower version of the game is in progress. Even residents in wheelchairs can play. Denise wanders ou Rose and Ben, back from their honeymoon participate. Ben makes a basket, Rose motors over, kisses him. Good-nature ad libs about "the mushy stage" .are HEARD.

(sotto to Rick)) Hey, I got more photos. (miming breasts) One has hooters to here. Rick glares at Derek, takes the ball out, throws it awkwa to Justine. She fakes out Max and sky-hooks a great hoop. Rick "high fives" her. Derek wolf whistles at Justine. He nudges Rick, whispers something dirty in Rick's ear. Rick loses his temper, pus Derek, who swings, landing a soft blow to Rick's arm.
Knock it off, guys. ‘
(pushing Rick) Yeah, re-tard knock it off.
(screaming) I am not retarded! oe

Rick punches Derek square in the face. Derek collapses li a broken doll. He rolis on the ground, blood spurting. Ri falls on him, grabs him by the throat. Denise jumps on Ri back, tries to pull him off Derek. The other residents SC at Rick to stop.

Stop it, Rick. Stop it. Look at me. Rick stops, looks in Denise's eyes. But he doesn't rememb her. She catches her breath, his rage intimidating. He lo at his’ swollen fist, at Derek writhing under him. Rick's mood swings from rage to confusion. He jumps off Derek, t to Denise. When his eyes finally register recognition he overwhelmed with sorrow.
I used to be different. I used to be, to be different... Denise chills at his panicked insight.
Help me. Help me find him. Please, I know you can help me.

Who? Find who... Rick grabs her around the waist, buries his head, sobbing Denise is embarrassed. His desperate, uncontrolled reacti unnerves her. She looks around for help but the residents have turned their attention to the bleeding Derek. cur To:
Denise on the phone, angry.
Mitch, it was an emergency...then the night nurse called in sick. DR. JAKE MAYER enters. In surgical greens, he is dishevel bushy-haired with wire-rimmed glasses.
(calls, mispronounces her name) Denise De..Fire..y.
a ala 25.

{to the doctor) DeFiore. That's me. Hold on. (into phone) I-gotta go. We'll talk about it later. Can I say goodnight to my son now? {forces a smile to Jake) Sam. I'll see you tomorrow. I love you, honey. Good night. (hanging up, to Jake) My kid. He's ten. With my ex. Why am I explaining myself? Jake is attracted to her.-It isn't mutual.
Jake Mayer, on-call-doc-for- Liberty~Street. At your service.
Quite a title.
Glad you like it. Denise gestures... "what about the guys?"
Oh right. Derek's nose'll be sore awhile though possibly not as long as his pride. I gave them a sedative. How about you?
What about me?
Catastrophic reactions can shake a person up...if she’s unprepared.
Thanks for the news flash.
How about dinner tomorrow night?
What about it?
You. Me. Lobster.
Do you always come on this strong?
(glances at his watch) Only when I've got about thirty seconds to make an impression.
No thanks.
If you change your mind....
---I know where to find you. cur TO:
Denise between Derek and Rick walking briskly to the van. There's still a stand-off. Denise halts.
Okay, shake hands.
He started it.
Did not.
It doesn't matter who started it. I'm ending it. Shake. A begrudging handshake. No eye contact. Denise climbs in van. Derek starts for shotgun just to annoy Rick.
My seat...that's my seat. Denise loses her temper. Over-reacts.
Enough. Both of you. Rick, get your butt in the back seat or walk home. Rick hangs his head, obeys, heartbroken. Derek is quieted Denise's outburst. She mutters..."I hate this job". cur To:
The house is quiet. Denise puts down a magazine, rubs her eyes. She feels a presence, turns. It's Rick, dressed in p.j's with his fedora.
And he's the last person she wants to see. She gets up quickly.
What, what are you doing?
Nothing. Making something to eat.
Grilled cheese.
What?

My favorite. I would eat, eat one every day. I used to make them... (straining for memory) ++-at least I think I did. But now, my..-.my..m..mom won't let me. She says I forget too much. Well. Goodnight. (a pause) I bugged you before. I, I do that a lot. I'm sorry. He turns to go. Feeling guilty, she softens.

Hey wait. {holding out a skillet) Nobody's around. Give it a whirl. Rick's eyes light up. He moves to the stove, takes the fr Pan. Denise turns on the griddle, tosses butter on it. Sh Slices the cheese, hands the slicer to Rick. He takes it, grateful, slices a piece.
Yeah, I think we got another Paul Prudomme on our hands.
Who? cur TO:
Denise and Rick are eating their way through a stack of grilled cheese sandwiches.
Thank...thank you for letting me...for letting me try.
